questions.text: The S2 sound is described regarding splitting and intensity. S2 is physiologically split in about 90% of people. The S2 heart sound can exhibit persistent (widened) splitting, fixed splitting, paradoxical (reversed) splitting or the absence of splitting. S2 is caused by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Closure of semilunar valves Option A : Closure of AV valves causes S1 Option C : First rapid filling phase causes S3 Option D : Second rapid filling phase causes S4

Highyeild:

S1 corresponds to mitral and tricuspid valve closure at the onset of systole S2 corresponds to aortic and pulmonary valve closure following ventricular ejection. S3-occurs during the rapid filling phase of ventricular diastole. S4 is sometimes physiological. More commonly, however, it is pathological, and occurs when it is required to augment filling of a hypertrophied, non-compliant ventricle (e.g. hypertension, aortic stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy). vigorous atrial contraction late in diastole

Random:

Explanation for Other Options Option A : Closure of AV valves causes S1 Option C : First rapid filling phase causes S3 Option D : Second rapid filling phase causes S4

questions.text: What are the causes of physiological splitting of S2?

options.label: A
options.text: Prolonged contraction time of the right ventricle delaying P2

options.label: B
options.text: Increased hangout interval before pulmonary valve closure

options.label: C
options.text: LV contraction generates less force than RV contraction causing aortic valve to close faster

questions.correct_answer: B. Increased hangout interval before pulmonary valve closure
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased hangout interval before pulmonary valve closure The RV contracts against a low-pressure system, i. e the pulmonary artery , therefore after the pressure of the RV becomes lower than pulmonary artery during contraction and ejection, flow continues by inertia for a relatively longer period of time (the hangout interval).

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : Both RV and LV have almost similar periods of contraction Option C : LV contraction generates more force than RV contraction, however since it is against a high pressure system (aorta), the hangout interval is less.

questions.text: An 8 year old child presents with episodes of “turning blue” in his childhood. On repeated enquiry history of an episode of fever with altered sensorium is elicited for which he was hospitalized and a surgery on his head was done. On auscultation an ejection systolic murmur with a loud S2 is heard. What will be the CXR finding?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Boot shaped heart This clinical picture of repeated cyanotic spells, with an episode suggestive of brain abscess (fever with altered sensorium and need of surgical treatment) along with an ejection systolic murmur with single S2 suggests a diagnosis of tetralogy of Fallot. The classical CXR found in ToF is a boot-shaped hear t. In ToF, due to subpulmonic stenosis, the hangout interval of the pulmonary circuit is decreased, resulting in P2 occurring much earlier, almost coinciding with A2, leading to a single S2.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : Water bag appearance is seen in pericardial effusion. No cyanotic spells are seen here Option B : Bat wing appearance is seen in cardiogenic pulmonary edema. In contrast, ToF is associated with pulmonary oligemia. Option D : Egg on string appearance is seen in transposition of great vessels. The presentation with cyanosis is much earlier, at or around birth.

questions.text: A 25 years old male is incidentally found to have an ASD during an echocardiogram before a major surgery. What type of S2 is characteristically heard in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Wide fixed split In ASD, the pressure across both the atria is equalized due to the septal defect. RV has more blood to eject and hence takes more time delaying P2 and the reverse occurs in the LV causing an early P2 . This combined with the equalization of pressures cancels out the respiratory variations causing a wide fixed split.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : Wide variable split is seen in RBBB, VSD, PS, Chronic pulmonary hypertension Option C : Reversed split is seen in LBBB, AS, Systemic hypertension Option D : Single S2 is seen in ToF, Eisenmenger syndrome.

questions.text: A 43-year-old male is brought to the ER after he suddenly became unresponsive. Patient had undergone operative fixation for a displaced hip fracture 3 weeks back. Despite CPR the patient crashed and could not be revived. The probable characteristic of S2 in in a less severe case would have been:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Narrow or absent split This is the characteristic clinical picture of a massive pulmonary embolism causing cardiac arrest. A sufficiently large embolism causes acute pulmonary hypertension . In such a scenario, the thin walled right ventricle cannot contract well against such a large resistance and the hangout time is decreased causing early P2 and hence a narrow split.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : It is seen in a number of causes including chronic pulmonary hypertension, where the RV is well adapted and hypertrophied, leading to a longer hangout time and delayed P2. Option C - Reverse splitting is seen in conditions that prolong LV hangout interval relative to the RV hangout interval resulting in delayed A2. Eg – Left bundle branch block, systemic hypertension, aortic stenosis . A single S2 may be heard on inspiration because of further prolongation of P2 due to greater volume to be ejected as a result of increased venous return, hence causing both the components to coincide. Option D - In ASD, the pressure across both the atria is equalized due to the septal defect. RV has more blood to eject and hence takes more time delaying P2 and the reverse occurs in the LV causing an early P2. This combined with the equalization of pressures cancels out the respiratory variations causing wide fixed split

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?

options.label: A
options.text: A wide variable split is heard in MR

options.label: B
options.text: A wide variable split is heard in TR

options.label: C
options.text: Single S2 is heard in ToF

options.label: D
options.text: Physiological splitting of S2 is absent in expiration

questions.correct_answer: B. A wide variable split is heard in TR
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A wide variable split is heard in TR In TR less volume of blood is ejected from RV due to incompetence, which leads to decreased pulmonary hangout time and early P2. Since the amount of blood reaching the left heart is also decreased , LV hangout time is also decreased causing early A2 . Hence splitting is narrow or absent in TR.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A : In MR, A2 is early because of incompetent mitral valve causing decompression into the atrium. However P2 is unaffected, causing a wide split Option C : The classical CXR finding in ToF is a boot shaped heart. In ToF, due to subpulmonic stenosis, the hangout interval of the pulmonary circuit is decreased, resulting in P2 occurring much earlier, almost coinciding with A2, leading to a single S2. Option D : In expiration P2 becomes earlier as there is less blood to be ejected from RV because of reduced venous return to the right heart.
